TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract sealed beforefieldinit IndexBatch extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides factory methods for creating a batch of document write operations to send to the search index.

MemberSignature.Value: public static Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models.IndexBatch<T> Merge<T> (System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<T> documents);
.method public static hidebysig class Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models.IndexBatch`1<!!T> Merge<T>(class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<!!T> documents) cil managed
Public Shared Function Merge(Of T) (documents As IEnumerable(Of T)) As IndexBatch(Of T)
static member Merge : seq<'T> -> Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models.IndexBatch<'T>

Docs.typeparam: The CLR type that maps to the index schema. Instances of this type can be stored as documents in the index.
Docs.param: The documents to merge; Set only the properties that you want to change.
Docs.summary: Creates a new IndexBatch for merging documents into existing documents in the index.

remarks.para: If type T contains non-nullable value-typed properties, these properties may not merge correctly. If you do not set such a property, it will automatically take its default value (for example, 0 for int or false for bool), which will override the value of the property currently stored in the index, even if this was not your intent. For this reason, it is strongly recommended that you always declare value-typed properties to be nullable in type T.
The above does not apply if you are using Document as type T.

MemberSignature.Value: public static Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models.IndexBatch<T> MergeOrUpload<T> (System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<T> documents);

static member MergeOrUpload : seq<'T> -> Microsoft.Azure.Search.Models.IndexBatch<'T>

Docs.typeparam: The CLR type that maps to the index schema. Instances of this type can be stored as documents in the index.
Docs.param: The documents to merge or upload.
Docs.summary: Creates a new IndexBatch for uploading documents to the index, or merging them into existing documents for those that already exist in the index.

remarks.para: If type T contains non-nullable value-typed properties, these properties may not merge correctly. If you do not set such a property, it will automatically take its default value (for example, 0 for int or false for bool), which will override the value of the property currently stored in the index, even if this was not your intent. For this reason, it is strongly recommended that you always declare value-typed properties to be nullable in type T.
The above does not apply if you are using Document as type T.
